## Vignette Goal
This vignette guides you through how to predict observations using the ridgereg() function.
In this case we will predict flight delays

## Function Discription
Ridgereg(formula, data, lambda) 
The function has three arguments.

Ridge regression can be a good alternative when we have a lot of covariates (when p > n) or in the situation of multicollinearity.

## Data
Read in the weather dataset and the flights dataset from the nycflights13 package and remove
eventual variables you do not believe to have a predictive value.
```
#### Step 1 ####
library(nycflights13)
library(dplyr)
data(weather)
data(flights)

delay_d <- select(flights,time_hour,origin,dep_delay)

# Subset JFK airport
delay_d_jfk <- filter(delay_d,origin == "JFK")

#### Step 2 #####

# Weather data
weather_d <- select(weather, time_hour,origin, wind_speed,precip,visib)

# Subset JFK airport
weather_d_jfk <- filter(weather_d, origin == "JFK")

# Match datasets by time_hour variable

delay_d_complete <- inner_join(delay_d_jfk, weather_d_jfk, by = "time_hour")
head(delay_d_complete)

#### Step 3 ####
install.packages("caret", dependencies = c("Depends", "Suggests"))
library(lattice)
library(ggplot2)
library(caret)

test_rows <- createDataPartition(y = delay_d_complete[1:10000,], p = 0.05, list = FALSE)
```
